Question:
Rearrange the parts of the sentence in the correct order.
P: And when they manifest our souls, our minds and bodies suffer from depression and anxiety.
Q: These negative states hide in our consciousness at different levels therefore they may manifest permanently or occasionally.
R: Egocentric fixation resides in negative states.
S: Meditation reveals the egocentric fixation and frees people from suffering because people are able to see their negative sides more clearly.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4 i.e. RQPS
The first line of the passage must be the one which introduces the theme of the paragraph. Out of all the sentences, sentence R is the starting line as it introduces the subject of the passage i.e. ‘egocentric fixation'.
The sentence R ends with the phrase ‘negative state’. Sentence Q describes the negative states. Hence, becoming the second sentence.
There is a mention of the word ‘manifest’ in the sentence Q which is further elaborated in the sentence P. Therefore, P is the third sentence.
Finally, sentence S provides the solution to egocentric fixation and hence becoming the last sentence of the passage.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the alternative which best expresses the meaning of the Idiom/Phrase.
Be in the red
Solution:
The correct answer is ‘To be in debt’.
Key Points
  • If a person or company is in the red or if their bank account is in the red, they have spent more money than they have in their account and therefore they owe money to the bank.
  • So, the meaning of the Idiom to be in the red means to be in debt.
    • For example: The company has been in the red for the last three quarters.
Hence, the correct answer is "option 3".

Question:
Rearrange the parts of the sentence in correct order.
P: It affords us a glimpse into acts, events, ideas, characters of the past, thus helping us to know more about those centuries gone by.
Q: It is almost as if such acts and ideas were to occur over and over again in different centuries though in a slightly different manner each time.
R: History is a record of past, especially in connection with human race.
S: When we trace history right from its beginning to the recent times, we cannot fail to notice that some events and characters have shown a repetitive quality.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2 i.e. RPSQ.
R is the first sentence of the paragraph as it introduces the theme of the passage i.e. ‘history’.
P should follow R as it describes what history provides us.
The next sentence should be S as it tells the characteristics of some events which we can get by tracing history from beginning to the recent times.
Finally, Q is the concluding statement.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Direct/Indirect speech. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Indirect/Direct speech.
My wife said to me, "This is a beautiful necklace!"
OP1: My wife told me that that was a beautiful necklace.
OP2: My wife told me this that was a beautiful necklace.
OP3: My wife told me that that is a beautiful necklace.
OP4: My wife told me this that is a beautiful necklace.
Solution:
The given sentence is in Direct Speech.
The given sentence is in Direct Speech because it quotes actual words. Therefore, it must be changed into Indirect Speech.
We notice that the reporting verb is in the Past tense (‘said’). Hence, a change will be made in the tense of the reported speech.
Also, the first person of the reported speech is changed according to the subject of reporting speech.
In the given question, ‘this’ is changed to ‘that’ and ‘is’ is changed to ‘was’.
Therefore, the sentence in Indirect Speech will be option 1 i.e. My wife told me that that was a beautiful necklace.

Question:
Read the passage carefully and choose the best answer to each question out of the four alternatives.
Eight north Indian Ocean countries, namely, Bangladesh, India, the Maldives, Myanmar, Oman, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, and Thailand, were asked to contribute names so that a combined list could be compiled. Each country gave eight names and a combined list of 64 names was prepared. This list is currently in use, and all cyclones arising in the north Indian Ocean are named from this list, with one name from each country being used in turn. Almost 38 or 39 names from the list have been used up, but since many cyclones dissipate long before they hit land, their names rarely figure in the papers or other media. The names that people do know about, and remember are, naturally, those that were most destructive ones, or very recent. Aila, in 2009 is remembered with a shudder for the enormous destruction it caused in West Bengal and Bangladesh; Phaillin, also for the damage it caused when it hit the Odisha coast in 2013. Two harmless cyclones, which also might remain in people’s memory, are the more recent ones of 2014 — Hudhud, which threatened the east coast of India and Nilofar, which was expected to, but did not, devastate the western coast. The names in the cyclone list are usually words that are associated with storms; words which mean water or wind or lightning in various national languages. Sometimes they are names of other things — birds or flowers or precious stones. The name ‘Aila’, contributed by the Maldives means ‘fire’, the name ‘Phaillin’ from Thailand means sapphire, the name ‘Hudhud’ from Oman is the name of a bird, probably the hoopoe, and the name ‘Nilofar’, given by Pakistan, is the Urdu name of the lotus or water lily. The eight names suggested by India, and which are in the list of 64, are Agni, Akaash, Bijli, Jal, Leher, Megh, Sagar, and Vayu, meaning in that order, fire, sky, lightning, water, wave, cloud, sea and wind. Five of these names (that is, up to Leher) have been used so far.

Question:

Solution:
The correct answer is option 2 i.e. Megh.
It can be inferred from the following lines: ‘The eight names suggested by India, and which are in the list of 64, are Agni, Akaash, Bijli, Jal, Leher, Megh, Sagar and Vayu, meaning in that order, fire, sky, lightning, water, wave, cloud, sea and wind. Five of these names (that is, up to Leher) have been used so far’.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select 'No Error'.
Our government has decided to strengthen the (1)/ States’ capacity to move away from a already (2)/ obsolete ‘one-size-fits-all’ approach. (3)/ No error. (4)
Solution:
The error is in the ‘second’ part of the sentence.
The article ‘an’ must be used before ‘already’ rather than ‘a’, because 'already' has a vowel sound.
Hence, the correct sentence will be: Our government has decided to strengthen the States’ capacity to move away from an already obsolete ‘one-size-fits-all’ approach.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select 'No Error'.
The viability of the multinational corporate system (1)/ depends upon the degree in which (2)/ people will tolerate the unevenness it creates. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in the second part of the sentence.
The preposition after degree must be ‘to’ rather than ‘in’. 'In' is a preposition of place, and is hence inappropriate here.
'To' is, however, often used ​to indicate a relationship between words, a relationship like possession, attachment, and addition.
Therefore, the correct sentence will be: The viability of the multinational corporate system depends upon the degree to which people will tolerate the unevenness it creates.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Direct/Indirect speech. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Indirect/Direct speech.
The Principal said to us, "Today you will get your diplomas."
OP1: The Principal told us that on that day we would get our diplomas.
OP2: The Principal told us this on that day we would be getting our diplomas.
OP3: The Principal told us that on this day we would be getting our diplomas.
OP4: The Principal told us this on that day we will be getting our diplomas.
Solution:
The given sentence is in Direct Speech.
The given sentence is in Direct Speech because it quotes actual words. Therefore, it must be changed into Indirect Speech.
We notice that the reporting verb is in the Past tense (‘said’). Hence, a change will be made in the tense of the reported speech.
Also, the first person of the reported speech is changed according to the subject of reporting speech.
In the given question, the pronoun ‘you' is changed to ‘us', the verb 'will get' is changed to 'would get' and ‘today’ is converted into ‘that day’.
Therefore, the sentence in Indirect Speech will be option 1 i.e. The Principal told us that on that day we would get our diplomas.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Direct/Indirect speech. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Indirect/Direct speech.
The leader said to his gang members, "Now I will tell you my plan."
OP1: The leader told the gang members that then he will tell them his plan.
OP2: The leader told the gang members that then he would tell them his plan.
OP3: The leader told the gang members that now he would tell them his plan.
OP4: The leader told the gang members that now he will tell them his plan.
Solution:
The given sentence is in Direct Speech.
The given sentence is in Direct Speech because it quotes actual words. Therefore, it must be changed into Indirect Speech.
We notice that the reporting verb is in the Past tense (‘said’). Hence, a change will be made in the tense of the reported speech.
Also, the first person of the reported speech is changed according to the subject of reporting speech.
In the given question, ‘I’ is changed to ‘he’, ‘now’ is changed to ‘then’ and ‘will’ is changed to ‘would’.
Therefore, the sentence in Indirect Speech will be option 2 i.e. The leader told the gang members that then he would tell them his plan.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Active/Passive voice. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Passive/Active voice.
This is the second time I have caught you cheating.
OP1: You have been caught cheating by me for the second time.
OP2: You were cheating for a second time and I have caught you.
OP3: This is the second time you have cheated and were caught by myself.
OP4: Catching you cheating for the second time has been done by me.
Solution:
Here the correct answer is You have been caught cheating by me for the second time.
Key Points:-
  • The given sentence is in the Active voice, therefore, it must be changed to the Passive voice.
  • In order to do that, we need to follow the given steps:-
  • The subject of the active voice 'I' will become the object of the passive voice 'me'.
  • The object of the active voice 'you' will become the subject of the passive voice.
  • The active voice is in present perfect tense.
  • Since the active voice is in the present perfect tense, therefore, it will follow the given structure:-
    • Active Voice - has/have + V3
    • Passive Voice - has/have + been + V3
  • Thus, 'have caught' (has/have + V3) will become 'have been caught' (has/have + been + V3).

Thus, the same sentence in the Passive voice is You have been caught cheating by me for the second time.
Additional Information
  • When we convert active voice to passive voice, three things need to be kept in mind:-
    • Change object into subject.
    • Change subject into object.
    • Always use third form of verb in passive voice.
    • Use 'by' before the new object.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Active/Passive voice. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Passive/Active voice.
Two engines are pulling the train up the hill.
OP1: The train will be pulled up the hill by two engines.
OP2: Up the hill pulling of the trains is being done by the two engines.
OP3: The train is being pulled up the hill by two engines.
OP4: Two engines are needed for pulling the train up the hill.
Solution:
The given sentence is in the Active voice, as the form of the verb (‘pulling’) shows that its subject (‘two engines’) was doing something and was ‘active’.
Therefore, it must be changed to the Passive voice, where something could be done by the subject, and it was ‘passive’.
In order to do that,
1. The object of the transitive verb in the Active voice should become the subject of the verb in the Passive voice (‘the train’ becomes the subject in place of ‘two engines’).
2. Add the appropriate form of the verb 'be' to the sentence and use the past participle of the verb (‘are pulling’ is converted to 'is being pulled').
3. Add a 'by' followed by the doer of the action.
Thus, the same sentence in the Passive voice is ‘The train is being pulled up the hill by two engines’.

In the following question, a sentence has been given in Direct/Indirect speech. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Indirect/Direct speech.
The pilgrim said to me, "When you go down the street you will see the temple to your right."
OP1: The pilgrim tells me that when I go down the street I will see the temple to my right.
OP2: The pilgrim told me that when I went down the street I would see the temple to my right.
OP3: The pilgrim told me that then I go down the street I would see the temple to my right.
OP4: The pilgrim tells me that when I would be going down the street I will be seeing the temple to my right.
Solution:
The given sentence is in Direct Speech.
The given sentence is in Direct Speech because it quotes actual words. Therefore, it must be changed into Indirect Speech.
We notice that the reporting verb is in the Past tense (‘said’). Hence, a change will be made in the tense of the reported speech.
Also, the first person of the reported speech is changed according to the subject of reporting speech.
In the given question, the pronoun 'you' is changed to 'I' and the verb ‘go’ is changed to 'went'.
Therefore, the sentence in Indirect Speech will be option 1 i.e. The pilgrim told me that when I went down the street I would see the temple to my right.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Active/Passive voice. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Passive/Active voice.
I will take the responsibility of failure.
OP1: I have been taking the responsibility of failure.
OP2: The responsibility of failure will be taken by me.
OP3: The responsibility of failing would have been taken by me.
OP4: Taking the responsibility of failure will be done by myself.
Solution:
The given sentence is in the Active voice, as the form of the verb (‘will take’) shows that its subject (‘I’) was doing something and was ‘active’.
Therefore, it must be changed to the Passive voice, where something could be done by the subject, and it was ‘passive’.
In order to do that,
1. The object of the transitive verb in the Active voice should become the subject of the verb in the Passive voice (‘The responsibility’ becomes the subject in place of ‘I’).
2. Add the appropriate form of the verb 'be' to the sentence and use the past participle of the verb (‘will take’ is converted to 'will be taken').
3. Add a 'by' followed by the doer of the action.
Thus, the same sentence in the Passive voice is ‘The responsibility of failure will be taken by me’.

Question:
Read the passage carefully and select the best answer to each question out of the given four alternatives.
Public opinion may be passive and false or active and real. It is claimed in theory that all governments are ultimately based on the opinion or sanction of the governed. But we find that in practice the people's rights are often trodden down and tyranny and oppression are allowed to continue. The government does it not because the people want it to do so but because they are too idle, too uneducated and too disunited or timid to oppose the government. Such public opinion is passive and false and not an active verdict. But when we find people alert, intelligent and determined to let the government know their will, when they want to exercise actively their voice in the management of their country, we have an instance of true or active public opinion. True public opinion is formed by and expressed through the press, the platform, political parties, and educational institutions. These have sacred duties to perform, duties on which depends the ultimate good of the entire community. The press today wields tremendous influence, so, it should support the causes and movements and condemn the wrong ones and thus teach people to form a correct opinion. A free and fair press ventilates the grievances of the public. Thus, a healthy relationship develops between the people and the government throughout an unbiased press. Political parties also help to create and regulate opinions. No less important part is played by the educational Institutions which train the minds of the young people who will be the citizens of tomorrow. It has been said that modern Germany and China have been made by their universities. It is necessary that the young and the growing minds should imbibe the spirit of fellow-feeling, the spirit of tolerance, the habit of compromise, and show due regard for the feelings and opinion of others without which a democratic society cannot function, let alone succeed. When there is a true awakening of the people, we shall have the real and conscious public opinion. And justice will reign on earth and truly will the voice of the people be the voice of God.

Solution:
The correct answer is option 1 i.e. press.
It is directly stated in the passage: ‘The press today wields tremendous influence, so, it should support the causes and movements and condemn the wrong ones and thus teach people to form a correct opinion’.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Active/Passive voice. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Passive/Active voice.
The taxi will drop you at the airport.
OP1: The taxi at the airport will be dropping you.
OP2: Dropping you at the airport will be done by the taxi.
OP3: You will be dropped at the airport by the taxi.
OP4: The taxi is dropping you at the airport.
Solution:
The given sentence is in the Active voice, as the form of the verb (‘will drop) shows that its subject (‘the taxi’) was doing something and was ‘active’.
Therefore, it must be changed to the Passive voice, where something could be done by the subject, and it was ‘passive’.
In order to do that,
1. The object of the transitive verb in the Active voice should become the subject of the verb in the Passive voice (‘you’ becomes the subject in place of ‘the taxi’).
2. Add the appropriate form of the verb 'be' to the sentence and use the past participle of the verb (‘will drop’ is converted to 'will be dropped').
3. Add a 'by' followed by the doer of the action.
Thus, the same sentence in the Passive voice is ‘You will be dropped at the airport by the taxi’.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the one which is opposite in meaning of the given word.
Ribald
Solution:
The meaning of the given words is:
Ribald: referring to sexual matters in an amusingly rude or irreverent way
Provision: the action of providing or supplying something for use
Biased: unfairly prejudiced for or against someone or something.
Clean: not sexually offensive or obscene
Vulgar: lacking sophistication or good taste
Therefore, clean is the opposite of ribald.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select 'No Error'.
Stringent penalties have a lower chance (1)/ of being imposed, as compared to fines that (2)/ are proportionate to the offend. (3)/ No error. (4)
Solution:
The error is in the third part of the sentence.
The usage of word ‘offend’ is incorrect. It should be ‘offence’ meaning ‘a breach of a law or rule; an illegal act’ to make the sentence grammatically correct.
Therefore, the correct sentence will be: Stringent penalties have a lower chance of being imposed, as compared to fines that are proportionate to the offence.

Question:
In the following question, out of the four alternatives, select the alternative which is the best substitute of the phrase.
Insatiable greed for riches
Solution:
The meaning of given words is:
Avarice: extreme greed for wealth or material gain
Actuary: a person who compiles and analyses statistics and uses them to calculate insurance risks and premiums
Antiquary: relating to or dealing in antiques or rare books
Apostate: a person who renounces a religious or political belief or principle
Therefore, the correct answer is option 1.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Direct/Indirect speech. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Indirect/Direct speech.
Juhi said to her friend, "I can choose to live the way I want to."
OP1: Juhi told her friend that she can choose to live the way she want to.
OP2: Juhi told her friend that she could be choosing to live the way she wants to.
OP3: Juhi told her friend that she chooses to live the way she wanted to.
OP4: Juhi told her friend that she could choose to live the way she wanted to.
Solution:
The given sentence is in Direct Speech.
The given sentence is in Direct Speech because it quotes actual words. Therefore, it has to be changed into Indirect Speech.
We notice that the reporting verb is in the Past tense (‘said’). Hence, a change will be made in the tense of the reported speech.
Also, the first person of the reported speech is changed according to the subject of reporting speech.
In the given question, the pronoun 'I' is changed to 'she' and the verb 'can choose' is changed to 'could choose'.
Therefore, the sentence in Indirect Speech will be option 4 i.e. Juhi told her friend that she could choose to live the way she wanted to.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the one which best expresses the meaning of the given word.
Fiendish
Solution:
The meaning of the given words is as follows:
Fiendish: extremely cruel or unpleasant
Apparent: clearly visible or understood
Cruel: wilfully causing pain or suffering to others, or feeling no concern about it
Secure: fixed or fastened so as not to give way, become loose, or be lost
Exemplify: be a typical example of
Therefore, fiendish is synonymous with cruel.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Active/Passive voice. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Passive/Active voice.
The city will build a new bridge across the river.
OP1: A new bridge across the river will be built by the city.
OP2: A bridge which is new will be built by the city.
OP3: Building of a new bridge will be done by the city.
OP4: The city will be building a new bridge across the river.
Solution:
The given sentence is in the Active voice, as the form of the verb (‘will build’) shows that its subject (‘the city’) was doing something and was ‘active’.
Therefore, it must be changed to the Passive voice, where something could be done by the subject, and it was ‘passive’.
In order to do that,
1. The object of the transitive verb in the Active voice should become the subject of the verb in the Passive voice (‘a new bridge’ becomes the subject in place of ‘city’).
2. Add the appropriate form of the verb 'be' to the sentence and use the past participle of the verb (‘will build’ is converted to 'will be built').
3. Add a 'by' followed by the doer of the action.
Thus, the same sentence in the Passive voice is ‘A new bridge across the river will be built by the city’.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Active/Passive voice. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Passive/Active voice.
She will hand over her papers to her company at the end of this month.
OP1: Handing over of the papers by her to her company would be done by her at the end of this month.
OP2: Her papers will be handed over by her to her company at the end of this month.
OP3: Her papers she will be handed over to her company at the end of this month.
OP4: At the end of this month her papers would have been handed over to her company by herself.
Solution:
The given sentence is in the Active voice, as the form of the verb (‘will hand’) shows that its subject (‘she’) was doing something and was ‘active’.
Therefore, it must be changed to the Passive voice, where something could be done by the subject, and it was ‘passive’.
In order to do that,
1. The object of the transitive verb in the Active voice should become the subject of the verb in the Passive voice (‘Her papers’ becomes the subject in place of ‘She’).
2. Add the appropriate form of the verb 'be' to the sentence and use the past participle of the verb (‘will be handed’ is converted to 'will hand').
3. Add a 'by' followed by the doer of the action.
Thus, the same sentence in the Passive voice is ‘Her papers will be handed over by her to her company at the end of this month’.

Question:
Rearrange the parts of the sentence in correct order.
P: When one gets solved or nears the solution, other starts raising its ugly head.
Q: Threats to our nation building processes are increasing day by day.
R: Tougher punishments should be provided for them in order to weed them out completely.
S: The need of the day is to go for integrated approach with taking steps to solve the poverty, illiteracy and population problems along with tough steps and stern action against the terrorists.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 1 i.e. QPSR.
Q is the first sentence of the passage as it introduces the theme of the paragraph i.e. threats to our nation.
P should follow Q as it describes that when we solve one problem, the other raises its head.
S should follow P as ‘PS’ forms a mandatory pair and S elaborates the steps one can take to face the threat which is faced by the country.
The concluding statement is hence R. It describes that strict punishments should be given to the terrorists so that they are weeded out completely.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the alternative which best expresses the meaning of the Idiom/Phrase.
Carry the can
OP1: To listen to something with considerable doubt
OP4: To take responsibility for some misdemeanour
Solution:
The correct answer is "To take responsibility for some misdemeanour"
Key Points
  • Let's see the meaning of the idiom "carry the can" is "take responsibility for a mistake or misdeed."
    • Example- As usual, I was left to carry the can.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Option 4.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Direct/Indirect speech. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Indirect/Direct speech.
“I will make for you the best rice you have ever had,” said the chef.
OP1: The chef told that he will make for him the best rice he has ever had.
OP2: The chef told him that he would make for him the best rice he had ever had.
OP3: The chef told that he will make for him the best rice he has ever have.
OP4: The chef tells that he would make for him the best rice he has ever had.
Solution:
The given sentence is in Direct Speech.
The given sentence is in Direct Speech because it quotes actual words. Therefore, it must be changed into Indirect Speech.
We notice that the reporting verb is in the Past tense (‘said’). Hence, a change will be made in the tense of the reported speech.
Also, the first person of the reported speech is changed according to the subject of reporting speech.
In the given question, the pronoun 'I' is changed to 'he', ‘you’ is changed to ‘him’ and ‘have’ is changed to ‘had’.
Therefore, the sentence in Indirect Speech will be option 2 i.e. The chef told him that he would make for him the best rice he had ever had.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Direct/Indirect speech. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Indirect/Direct speech.
She said to me, "I always drink a cup of green tea as soon as I get up."
OP1: She told me that she always drinks a cup of green tea as soon as she gets up.
OP2: She told me that she always drunk a cup of green tea as soon as she got up.
OP3: She had told me that she always drinks a cup of green tea as soon as she got up.
OP4: She told me that she always drank a cup of green tea as soon as she would be getting up.
Solution:
The correct answer is Option 1) i.e. She told me that she always drinks a cup of green tea as soon as she gets up.
Key Points
The given sentence is in Direct Speech because it quotes actual words. Therefore, it must be changed into Indirect Speech.
  • Although we change the verbs to past tense, in this case, a habit or a regular activity is being talked about.
  • Reporting Verb will be changed into 'told'
  • Hence, the quoted part will remain in the present tense since the action is repeated every day.
  • "I" will turn into "she" and the verbs will be changed according to the third person i.e. "drink" and "get" will become "drinks" and "gets".
Therefore, the sentence in Indirect Speech will be option 1 i.e. She told me that she always drinks a cup of green tea as soon as she gets up.
Important Points
Whenever a habitual action is being talked about, there is no change in tense made while converting direct speech into indirect speech.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the one which best expresses the meaning of the given word.
Esoteric
Solution:
The meaning of the given words is as follows:
Esoteric: intended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people with a specialised knowledge or interest
Befitting: appropriate to the occasion
Abstruse: difficult to understand; obscure
Relevant: closely connected or appropriate to what is being done or considered
Therefore, abstruse is synonymous with esoteric.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select 'No Error'.
The vast majority of people are consuming (1)/ suboptimal amounts of most micronutrients (2)/ and most of the micronutrients concerning are very safe. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in the third part of the sentence.
The flaw is because of the presence of the incorrect form of the word ‘concern’. The adjective form of the word i.e. ‘concerning’ must be replaced with the verb form concerned.
The correct sentence will be:
The vast majority of people are consuming suboptimal amounts of most micronutrients and most of the micronutrients concerned are very safe.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select 'No Error'.
Buttressing the confidence in the economy (1)/ are the findings in the survey, which posits (2)/ an improvement in the infrastructure sectors.(3)/ No error. (4)
Solution:
The error is in the second part of the sentence.
Key Points
  • In the given sentence 'Buttressing' Gerund is a subject which is singular hence the verb will be used in singular form
  • Thus 'are' will be replaced by 'is' to make the sentence grammatically correct
Therefore, the correct sentence will be: Buttressing the confidence in the economy is the findings in the survey, which posits an improvement in the infrastructure sectors.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Active/Passive voice. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Passive/Active voice.
The authorities are mistreating the prisoners.
OP1: The prisoners will be mistreated by the authorities.
OP3: The prisoners are being mistreated by the authorities.
OP4: Mistreating of the prisoners will be done by the authorities.
Solution:
The given sentence is in the Active voice, as the form of the verb (‘mistreating’) shows that its subject (‘the authorities’) was doing something and was ‘active’.
Therefore, it must be changed to the Passive voice, where something could be done by the subject, and it was ‘passive’.
In order to do that,
1. The object of the transitive verb in the Active voice should become the subject of the verb in the Passive voice (‘the prisoners’ becomes the subject in place of ‘the authorities’).
2. Add the appropriate form of the verb 'be' to the sentence and use the past participle of the verb (‘are mistreating’ is converted to 'are being mistreated').
3. Add a 'by' followed by the doer of the action.
Thus, the same sentence in the Passive voice is ‘The prisoners are being mistreated by the authorities’.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
The purpose of speaking is to communicate, (I chose words that are the best) for the idea I want to convey.
OP1: I am choosing words that were the best
OP2: I did choose words that are the best
OP3: I choose words that are the best
Solution:
The correct answer s option 3 i.e. I choose words that are the best.
'Chose' is the past form of the verb 'choose'. Since the sentence is in the present tense, option 3 is the correct option.
The sentence will be: The purpose of speaking is to communicate, I choose words that are the best for the idea I want to convey.

Question: In the following question, four words have been written, out of which only one is incorrectly spelt. Select the incorrectly spelt word.
Solution:
The correct answer is 'Concomittant'.
Key Points
  • The incorrectly spelt word is 'Concomittant'.
  • The word's correct spelling is 'concomitant'- naturally accompanying or associated. (स्वाभाविक रूप से जुड़ा हुआ)
  • E.g.- The drug's risks increase with the concomitant use of alcohol.
    Additional Information
  • Coalescence: the process of coming or growing together to form one thing or system (एक समूह में एकजुट होना या एक साथ आना)
  • Complaisance: willingness to please others by being polite and fitting in with their plans (ऐसे गुण होना जो किसी को पसंद आएं)
  • Commissariat: a department for the supply of food and equipment (एक सैन्य विभाग जो भोजन और उपकरण की आपूर्ति करता है)

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the alternative which best expresses the meaning of the Idiom/Phrase.
Be a dab hand at something
OP3: Ready to listen to other people's conversation
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4 i.e. ‘skilled in a particular area’.
For example: She's always been a dab hand with a paint brush.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select 'No Error'.
India, a country of more than 1 billion (1)/ population, is emerged as the (2)/ economic superpower of the world. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in the second part of the sentence. The presence of the verb ‘is’ is incorrect. It should be ‘has’ to make the sentence grammatically correct.
The correct sentence will be: India, a country of more than 1 billion population, has emerged as the economic superpower of the world.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Active/Passive voice. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Passive/Active voice.
I will not allow you to ride that motorcycle.
OP1: I will not be allowing riding that motorcycle by you.
OP2: You will not be allowed to ride that motorcycle (by me).
OP3: You had not been allowed by myself riding that motorcycle.
OP4: Riding of that motorcycle by you has not been allowed by me.
Solution:
The given sentence is in the Active voice, as the form of the verb (‘will not allow you’) shows that its subject (‘I’) was doing something and was ‘active’.
Therefore, it must be changed to the Passive voice, where something could be done by the subject, and it was ‘passive’.
In order to do that,
1. The object of the transitive verb in the Active voice should become the subject of the verb in the Passive voice (‘You’ becomes the subject in place of ‘I’).
2. Add the appropriate form of the verb 'be' to the sentence and use the past participle of the verb (‘will not allow you’ is converted to 'will not be allowed').
3. Add a 'by' followed by the doer of the action. This can also be left out since the sentence can work without the subject of the sentence.
Thus, the same sentence in the Passive voice is ‘You will not be allowed to ride that motorcycle (by me).’.

Question:
Rearrange the parts of the sentence in correct order.
P: His story symbolizes a lifestyle struggle against apartheid in South Africa
Q: ‘Nelson Mandela’ was born on July 18th 1918 in the village of Mvezo in Umtata, then a part of South Africa’s cape Province.
R: It was a terrible form of institutionalized racism that held the South African society in its grip for a long time
S: It was not easy for Mandela to fight against it, as he too was among those who were oppressed by the system.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3 i.e. QPRS.
The first line of the passage must be the one which introduces the theme of the paragraph. Out of all the sentences, sentence Q is the starting line as it introduces the subject of the passage i.e. ‘Nelson Mandela’.
P should follow Q as it gives the hint of the life he lived.
R should follow P that tells us the type of racism which was held in South Africa, the hint for which is given in the sentence P.
Finally, S should conclude the passage which tells that it was not easy for Mandela to fight against racism.

Question:
In the following question, out of the four alternatives, select the alternative which is the best substitute of the phrase.
Mountain climbing
Solution:
The meaning of the given words is:
Alienisms: an obsolete term for the study and treatment of mental illness
Alpinism: mountain climbing
Albinism: a congenital disorder characterized by the complete or partial absence of pigment in the skin, hair and eyes
Algorism: the technique of performing basic arithmetic by writing numbers in place value form and applying a set of memorized rules and facts to the digits
Therefore, option 2 is the correct answer.

Question:

Even after putting his body and soul, if he fails to achieve victory he will not have (any authority above others).
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2 i.e. any authority over others.
'Authority over' means 'ability to control'.
The sentence will be: Even after putting his body and soul, if he fails to achieve victory he will not have any authority over others.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
Perhaps a greater challenge they face is (improving the wounds of the civil war), Iraq is a divided country today.
OP1: Counting the effects of the civil war
OP2: Curing the aftermaths of the civil war
OP3: Healing the wounds of the civil war
Solution:
The correct answer is Healing the wounds of the civil war.
Key Points
  • There is no collocation between the words wound and improve.
  • So, they are creating an error here.
  • The correct word that has a collocation with wound is healing.
  • Healing means to make or become well again, especially after a cut or other injury.
  • So, the correct answer is option 3 i.e. ‘healing the wounds of the civil war’ as it is the only phrase that makes the sentence grammatically and contextually correct.
The correct sentence will be: Perhaps a greater challenge they face is healing the wounds of the civil war, Iraq is a divided country today.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Active/Passive voice. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Passive/Active voice.
To pass, the candidate has to answer at least three questions correctly.
OP1: If the candidate answers three questions correctly then he will pass.
OP2: At least three questions will be answered correctly by the candidate to pass.
OP3: At least three questions have to be answered correctly by the candidate to pass.
OP4: Answering of three questions correctly by the candidate has to be done to pass.
Solution:
Here the correct answer is At least three questions have to be answered correctly by the candidate to pass.
Key Points:-
  • The given sentence is in the Active voice, therefore, it must be changed to the Passive voice.
  • Let's follow the given steps to convert the given sentence into passive voice:-
    • The subject of the active voice 'the candidate' will become the object of the passive voice.
    • The object of the active voice 'at least three questions' will become the subject of the passive voice.
    • The active voice contains an infinitive 'to answer'.
    • Whenever an infinitive (to + V1) is used in the active voice, it is changed according to the following structure:-
      • Active Voice - Subject + verb + to + V1 + Object.
      • Passive Voice - Object + verb + to + be + V3 + by + Subject.
    • Thus, 'has to answer' (verb + to + V1) is converted to 'have to be answered' (verb + to + be + V3).
Thus, the same sentence in the Passive voice is At least three questions have to be answered correctly by the candidate to pass.
Additional Information
  • When we convert active voice to passive voice, three things need to be kept in mind:-
    • Change object into subject.
    • Change subject into object.
    • Always use the third form of the verb in the passive voice.
    • Use 'by' before the new object.

Question: In the following question, four words have been written out of which only one is incorrectly spelt. Select the incorrectly spelt word.
Solution:
Option 4 i.e. ‘accruemant’ is spelt wrongly. It is correctly spelt as ‘accruement meaning ‘to come to one as a gain, addition, or increment’
The meaning of other words is:
Abhorrent: inspiring disgust and loathing
Abstinent: refraining from an activity or from the consumption of something, especially alcohol
Achievement: a thing done successfully with effort, skill, or courage

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Direct/Indirect speech. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Indirect/Direct speech.
The beggar said to her, “Thank you for your kindness.”
OP1: The beggar thanks her for her kindness.
OP2: The beggar says thanks for her kindness.
OP3: The beggar thanks for her kindness.
OP4: The beggar thanked her for her kindness.
Solution:
The given sentence is in Direct Speech.
The given sentence is in Direct Speech because it quotes actual words. Therefore, it must be changed into Indirect Speech.
We notice that the reporting verb is in the Past tense (‘said’). Hence, a change will be made in the tense of the reported speech.
Also, the first person of the reported speech is changed according to the subject of reporting speech.
In the given question, ‘you’ is changed to ‘her’.
Therefore, the sentence in Indirect Speech will be option 4 i.e. The beggar thanked her for her kindness.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence is given with a blank to be filled in with an appropriate word. Select the correct alternative out of the four and indicate it by selecting the appropriate option.
A metrical thinker should always be moving in a direction which is beneficial and right at every ______.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2 i.e. ‘stride’ meaning ‘a step or stage in progress towards an aim’.
The meanings of the other words are:
Height: the measurement of someone or something from head to foot or from base to top.
Growth: the process of increasing in size.
Address: the particulars of the place where someone lives or an organisation is situated.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the one which best expresses the meaning of the given word.
Crescendo
Solution:
The meaning of the given words is as follows:
Crescendo: increase in loudness or intensity.
Dominate: have power and influence over
Escalation: an increase in the intensity
Squander: waste (something, especially money or time) in a reckless and foolish manner
Revere: feel deep respect or admiration for (something)
Therefore, crescendo is synonymous with escalation.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the alternative which best expresses the meaning of the Idiom/Phrase.
Foot the bill
OP1: To get good discount on a total bill
OP4: To avoid paying for little expenses
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2 i.e. ‘to pay for something’.
For example: The bride's father was resigned to footing the bill for the wedding.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select 'No Error'.
She was so overwhelmed with her (1)/ sons’ devotion and affection that she (2)/ did distributed all her wealth and property among them. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in the third part of the sentence.
The formation 'did+3rd form of the verb' ('did distrubted') is grammatically incorrect. 'Did' is always followed by the first form of the verb.
Additionally, the formation 'did+1st form of the verb' is usually used for emphasis. But it is considered incorrect if one is just stating a fact.
Hence, the correct sentence will be: She was so overwhelmed with her sons' devotion an affection that she distributed all her wealth and property among them.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select 'No Error'.
Together with empowerment, there has (1)/ to be a culture of personally accountability (2)/ so that everyone realizes the necessity of valuing commitment. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in the second part of the sentence.
To make the sentence grammatically correct, ‘personally’ must be replaced with ‘personal’. The use of the adverb form of the word 'personal' is incorrect because the sentence is talking about a culture of a kind of accountability; i.e. 'personal accountability.'
The correct sentence will be: Together with empowerment, there has to be a culture of personal accountability so that everyone realizes the necessity of valuing commitment.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
They will not be able to enjoy these (up and until) they part with their personal biometric information to the government.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2 i.e. unless and until.
The phrase ‘unless and until’ is a set phrase which is used as a conjunction to connect sentences.
The correct sentence will be: They will not be able to enjoy these unless and until they part with their personal biometric information to the government.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Active/Passive voice. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Passive/Active voice.
You have to take these medicines.
OP1: These medicines you have to take.
OP3: These medicines have to be taken by you.
OP4: Taking of these medicines has to be done by you.
Solution:
The given sentence is in the Active voice, as the form of the verb (‘have to take’) shows that its subject (‘you’) was doing something and was ‘active’.
Therefore, it must be changed to the Passive voice, where something could be done by the subject, and it was ‘passive’.
In order to do that,
1. The object of the transitive verb in the Active voice should become the subject of the verb in the Passive voice (‘medicines’ becomes the subject in place of ‘you’).
2. Add the appropriate form of the verb 'be' to the sentence and use the past participle of the verb (‘have to take’ is converted to 'have to be taken').
3. Add a 'by' followed by the doer of the action.
Thus, the same sentence in the Passive voice is ‘These medicines have to be taken by you’.

Question:
Rearrange the parts of the sentence in correct order.
P: The Mughal empire was extensive, but it was not integrated.
Q: It was rather an agglomeration of territories bound together by a common administration and common ties to the imperial authority.
R: The strong hand of the emperor held the country together, compelling obedience from the nobles who governed the provinces.
S: But these nobles felt no sense of national loyalty, for the simple reason that the empire was not a nation.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3 i.e. PRSQ.
P must be the first sentence as it introduces the theme of the passage i.e. the Mughal empire.
R must follow P as it tells about the role of the emperor and the nobles.
S must follow R. ‘But’ in the beginning gives us the hint that it should follow R because it talks about the fact mentioned in sentence R.
Finally, Q is the concluding statement.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence is given with a blank to be filled in with an appropriate word. Select the correct alternative out of the four and indicate it by selecting the appropriate option.
Galileo was the first scientist to recognize clearly that the only way to further our understanding of the physical world was to______ to experiment.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2 i.e. resort.
The phrase ‘resort to’ means ‘turn to and adopt (a course of action, especially an extreme or undesirable one) so as to resolve a difficult situation’.
The meanings of the given words are:
Annihilate: destroy utterly; obliterate.
Emerge: move out of or away from something and become visible.
Suspect: have an idea or impression of the existence, presence, or truth of (something) without certain proof.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Direct/Indirect speech. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Indirect/Direct speech.
My friend said to me, "I think she will not accept your proposal."
OP1: My friend told me that he thought that she would not accept my proposal.
OP2: My friend says to me that he thinks that she will not accept my proposal.
OP3: My friend told me that he thinks that she will not be accepting my proposal.
OP4: My friend told me that that he thought she would not be accepting my proposal.
Solution:
The given sentence is in Direct Speech.
The given sentence is in Direct Speech because it quotes actual words. Therefore, it must be changed into Indirect Speech.
We notice that the reporting verb is in the Past tense (‘said’). Hence, a change will be made in the tense of the reported speech.
Also, the first person of the reported speech is changed according to the subject of reporting speech.
In the given question, the pronoun 'I' is changed to 'he', ‘your’ is converted into ‘my’ and the verb ‘think’ is changed to 'thought'.
Therefore, the sentence in Indirect Speech will be option 1 i.e. My friend told me that he thought that she would not accept my proposal.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the alternative which best expresses the meaning of the Idiom/Phrase.
A hair’s breadth
OP1: Telling about the smallest possible amount or degree of something
OP2: Irresponsible pleasure sealing in an old age
OP4: Looking for something which is not clearly visible
Solution:
The correct answer is option 1 i.e. ‘Telling about the smallest possible amount or degree of something’.
For example: She came within a hair's breadth of losing her life.

Question:
Rearrange the parts of the sentence in correct order.
P: In the least-developed countries, if agricultural productivity were drastically reduced by climate change, the cost of living would rise by one or two percent, and at a time when per capita income will likely have doubled.
Q: It may still be vulnerable to climate change for many years to come
R: In developing countries, in contrast, as much as a third of GNP and half the population currently depends on agriculture.
S: Agriculture is practically the only sector of the economy affected by climate.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3 i.e. PRQS.
The first line of the passage must be the one which introduces the theme of the paragraph. Out of all the sentences, sentence P is the starting line as it introduces the subject of the passage i.e. ‘developing countries.'
Since only option 3 has P as the first sentence, it is the correct option.
Note: In the official exam, option 3 was RPSQ, which was incorrect and hence there was no correct answer given in the official answer key. We have however changed the option for the clarity of the students.

Question:
Rearrange the parts of the sentence in correct order.
P: In addition, tsunamis move throughout the depth of the ocean and not just its surface.
Q: A tsunami isn’t much different in height compared to other waves in the ocean.
R: That is why a tsunami generally goes unnoticed in the open ocean.
S: But, due to its wavelength, it “piles up” when it approaches land.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3 i.e. QSPR.
The first line of the passage must be the one which introduces the theme of the paragraph. Out of all the sentences, sentence P is the starting line as it introduces the subject of the passage i.e. ‘Tsunami’.
Since only option 3 contains Q as the starting sentence, it is the answer.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
The Centre should revisit (their) draft and incorporate the inputs of the report submitted by the standing committee and an expert panel.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 1 i.e. its because the subject is singular i.e. Centre.
'Their' is used to show possession for the plural pronoun 'they'. But here, since the subject is 'the Centre', 'its' is correct.
The sentence will be: The Centre should revisit its draft and incorporate the inputs of the report submitted by the standing committee and an expert panel.

Question:
Rearrange the parts of the sentence in correct order.
P: Children with good manners are liked by one and all.
Q: They are appreciated even by strangers.
R: All round development of a child is possible only if a child is groomed in good manners.
S: Therefore, the public school lay great emphasis on the cultivation of good manners in their students.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 1 i.e. PQRS
The first line of the passage must be the one which introduces the theme of the paragraph. Out of all the sentences, sentence P is the starting line as it introduces the subject of the passage i.e. ‘Children with good manners’.
Since only option 1 contains P as the starting sentence, it is the answer.

Question:
Rearrange the parts of the sentence in correct order.
P: But our behaviour, ‘good’ or ‘bad’, certainly shapes our persona and determines our personality.
Q: If one is helpful, polite and considerate in one’s actions towards fellow-beings, one is known as a kind person.
R: The converse is equally true and a mean, rude and selfish person is regarded as bad.
S: Growing urbanisation and lack of roots in any given place have made us increasingly indifferent to the feelings of others and led us to adopt an apathetic attitude to most things.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3 i.e. SPQR.
S is the first sentence of the paragraph as it introduces the theme of the passage i.e. ‘growing urbanisation and lack of roots’.
P should follow S. P describes that although we have adopted apathetic attitude to most things, our behaviour defines our personality.
Q follows P as it elaborates the point discussed in sentence P.
R is thus the concluding statement.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Active/Passive voice. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Passive/Active voice.
Have you created this beautiful artwork?
OP1: Had you been creating this beautiful artwork?
OP2: Had you created this beautiful artwork?
OP3: Has this beautiful artwork been created by you?
OP4: Has creating this beautiful artwork been done by you?
Solution:
The given sentence is in the Active voice, as the form of the verb (‘created’) shows that its subject (‘you’) was doing something and was ‘active’.
Therefore, it must be changed to the Passive voice, where something could be done by the subject, and it was ‘passive’.
In order to do that,
1. The question words do not change their position at the beginning of the sentence when the active voice is changed into the passive voice
2. Add the appropriate form of the verb 'be' to the sentence and use the past participle of the verb (‘created’ is converted to ‘been created’).
Thus, the same sentence in the Passive voice is ‘Has this beautiful artwork been created by you?’

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Direct/Indirect speech. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Indirect/Direct speech.
She said to the shopkeeper, "My favourite colour is yellow."
OP1: She informs the shopkeeper that her favourite colour is yellow.
OP2: She told the shopkeeper that her favourite colour is yellow.
OP3: She told the shopkeeper that her favourite colour was yellow.
OP4: She tells the shopkeeper that her favourite colour is yellow.
Solution:
The given sentence is in Direct Speech. Therefore, it must be changed into Indirect Speech.
'She said' indicates that it was reported in the past. So, the tense of the reported speech should be changed accordingly.
'colour is' changes to 'colour was'.
The indirect form is: She told the shopkeeper that her favourite colour was yellow.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Direct/Indirect speech. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Indirect/Direct speech.
He said to the principal, "I have made a mistake."
OP1: He told the principal that I have had made a mistake.
OP2: He told the principal that he had made a mistake.
OP3: He tells the principal that he has made a mistake.
OP4: He told the principal this that he has made a mistake.
Solution:
The given sentence is in Direct Speech.
The given sentence is in Direct Speech because it quotes actual words. Therefore, it must be changed into Indirect Speech.
We notice that the reporting verb is in the Past tense (‘said’). Hence, a change will be made in the tense of the reported speech.
Also, the first person of the reported speech is changed according to the subject of reporting speech.
In the given question, ‘I’ is changed to ‘he’ and ‘have’ is changed to ‘had’.
Therefore, the sentence in Indirect Speech will be option 2 i.e. He told the principal that he had made a mistake.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
(Like instance), you can reduce or increase your total deposit amount some time or even change the sum fixed.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2 i.e. for instance.
The phrase 'for instance' means 'as an example'. The other options; 'as instance', 'in instance', are incorrect.
The sentence will be: For instance, you can reduce or increase your total deposit amount some time or even change the sum fixed.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Active/Passive voice. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Passive/Active voice.
I am putting my life at a stranger’s feet.
OP1: At the stranger's feet my life has been put by myself.
OP2: My life will put by me at a stranger's feet.
OP3: My life is being put by me at a stranger's feet.
OP4: Putting of my life at the stranger's feet has been done my me.
Solution:
The given sentence is in the Active voice, as the form of the verb (‘am putting’) shows that its subject (‘I’) was doing something and was ‘active’.
Therefore, it must be changed to the Passive voice, where something could be done by the subject, and it was ‘passive’.
In order to do that,
1. The object of the transitive verb in the Active voice should become the subject of the verb in the Passive voice (‘my life’ becomes the subject in place of ‘I’).
2. Add the appropriate form of the verb 'be' to the sentence and use the past participle of the verb (‘am putting’ is converted to 'is being put').
3. Add a 'by' followed by the doer of the action.
Thus, the same sentence in the Passive voice is ‘My life is being put by me at a stranger's feet’.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
Not only do they heighten anxieties among the (targeted groups rather also they) risk giving the unacceptable a perverse acceptability.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3 i.e. targeted groups but also they.
The sentence uses the 'not only..but also' formation. To add emphasis, we can use 'not only' at the beginning of a clause. When we do this, we invert the subject and the verb.
The sentence will be: Not only do they heighten anxieties among the targeted groups but also they risk giving the unacceptable a perverse acceptability.

Question:
Read the passage carefully and select the best answer to each question out of the given four alternatives.
The Amazon basin has been continuously inhabited for at least 10, 000 years, possibly more. Its earliest inhabitants were stone-age peoples, living in hundreds of far-flung tribes, some tiny, others numbering in the tens of thousands. It was from the west that Europeans explorers first arrived. In 1541 a Spanish expedition from Quito, led by Gonzalo Pizarro, ran short of supplies while exploring east of the Andes in what is today Peru. Pizarro’s cousin Francisco de Orellana offered to take 60 men along with the boats from the expedition and forage for supplies. De Orellana floated down the Rio Napo to its confluence with the Amazon, near Iquitos (Peru), and then to the mouth of the Amazon. Along the way his expedition suffered numerous attacks by Indians; some of the Indian warriors, they reported, were female, like the Amazons of Greek mythology, and thus the world’s greatest river got its name. No one made a serious effort to claim this sweaty territory, however, until the Portuguese built a fort near the mouth of the river at Belém in 1616, and sent Pedro Teixeira up the river to Quito and back between 1637 and 1639. During the 17th and 18th centuries, Portuguese Bandeirantes (groups of roaming adventurers) penetrated ever further into the rainforest in pursuit of gold and Indian slaves, exploring as far as present-day Rondônia, and the Guaporé and Madeira river valleys. Amazonian Indians had long used the sap from rubber trees to make waterproof bags and other items. European explorers recognized the potential value of natural latex but were unable to market it because it tended to grow soft in the heat, or brittle in the cold, and thus had limited appeal outside the rainforest. However, in 1842 American Charles Goodyear developed vulcanization (made natural rubber durable) and in 1890 Ireland’s John Dunlop patented pneumatic rubber tires. Soon there was an unquenchable demand for rubber in the recently industrialized USA and Europe, and the price of rubber on international markets soared. As profits skyrocketed, so did exploitation of the seringueiros, or rubber tappers, who were lured into the Amazon, mostly from the drought-stricken northeast, by the promise of prosperity only to be locked into a cruel system of virtual slavery dominated by seringalistas (owners of rubber-bearing forests). Rigged scales, hired guns, widespread illiteracy among the rubber tappers, and monopoly of sales and purchases all combined to perpetuate the workers’ debt and misery. In addition, seringueiros had to contend with jungle fevers, Indian attacks and all manner of deprivation.

Question:
From where did the European explorers first arrive?
Solution:
The correct answer is option 1 i.e. ‘The West’.
It can be deduced from the following line: It was from the west that Europeans explorers first arrived.

Amazonian Indians had long used the sap from rubber trees to make waterproof bags and other items. European explorers recognized the potential value of natural latex but were unable to market it because it tended to grow soft in the heat, or brittle in the cold, and thus had limited appeal outside the rainforest. However, in 1842 American Charles Goodyear developed vulcanization (made natural rubber durable) and in 1890 Ireland’s John Dunlop patented pneumatic rubber tires. Soon there was an unquenchable demand for rubber in the recently industrialized USA and Europe, and the price of rubber on international markets soared. As profits skyrocketed, so did exploitation of the seringueiros, or rubber tappers, who were lured into the Amazon, mostly from the drought-stricken northeast, by the promise of prosperity only to be locked into a cruel system of virtual slavery dominated by seringalistas (owners of rubber-bearing forests). Rigged scales, hired guns, widespread illiteracy among the rubber tappers, and monopoly of sales and purchases all combined to perpetuate the workers’ debt and misery. In addition, seringueiros had to contend with jungle fevers, Indian attacks and all manner of deprivation.

Question:
'Seringalistas' refers to ________.
Solution: The correct answer is option 2 i.e. owners of rubber bearing forests.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Active/Passive voice. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Passive/Active voice.
They will start the fireworks at 10:00 pm sharp.
OP1: The fireworks will be started by them at 10:00 pm sharp.
OP2: They themselves will be starting the fireworks at 10:00 pm sharp.
OP3: The fireworks would be started by themselves at 10:00 pm sharp.
OP4: Starting of the fireworks will be done by them at 10:00 pm sharp.
Solution:
The given sentence is in the Active voice, as the form of the verb (‘will start’) shows that its subject (‘they’) was doing something and was ‘active’.
Therefore, it must be changed to the Passive voice, where something could be done by the subject, and it was ‘passive’.
In order to do that,
1. The object of the transitive verb in the Active voice should become the subject of the verb in the Passive voice (‘The fireworks’ becomes the subject in place of ‘They’).
2. Add the appropriate form of the verb 'be' to the sentence and use the past participle of the verb (‘will be started’ is converted to 'will start').
3. Add a 'by' followed by the doer of the action.
Thus, the same sentence in the Passive voice is ‘The fireworks will be started by them at 10:00 pm sharp’.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select 'No Error'.
A judge must be slow in anger and (1)/ quick to forgive; otherwise he may (2)/ risk abusing his powers.(3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The correct answer is 'Option 1'.
Key Points
  • The error lies in the first part of the sentence.
  • The error is because of the incorrect phrase i.e. ‘slow in anger’.
  • It must be ‘slow to anger’.
  • The phrase ‘slow to anger’ means ‘patient’.
Therefore, the correct sentence will be: A judge must be slow to anger and quick to forgive; otherwise he may risk abusing his powers.

The sentence will be: Students who attempted the question paper have met some of their professors, seeking informed answers to these questions.

Question:

Grandmother is knitting a sweater for you.

OP3: Grandmother is knitting for you a sweater.
OP4: Knitting of a sweater has been done by grandmother for you.
Solution:
The given sentence is in the Active voice, as the form of the verb (‘knitting’) shows that its subject (‘’grandmother) was doing something and was ‘active’.
Therefore, it must be changed to the Passive voice, where something could be done by the subject, and it was ‘passive’.
In order to do that,
1. The object of the transitive verb in the Active voice should become the subject of the verb in the Passive voice (‘sweater’ becomes the subject in place of ‘grandmother’).
2. Add the appropriate form of the verb 'be' to the sentence and use the past participle of the verb (‘is knitting’ is converted to 'being knit').
3. Add a 'by' followed by the doer of the action.
Thus, the same sentence in the Passive voice is ‘A sweater is being knit by grandmother for you’.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Active/Passive voice. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Passive/Active voice.
I could not find the book.
OP1: I myself can not find the book.
OP2: The book could not be found by me.
OP3: By me the book can not be found.
OP4: Finding of the book could not be done by me.
Solution:
The given sentence is in the Active voice, as the form of the verb (‘find’) shows that its subject (‘I’) was doing something and was ‘active’.
Therefore, it must be changed to the Passive voice, where something could be done by the subject, and it was ‘passive’.
In order to do that,
1. The object of the transitive verb in the Active voice should become the subject of the verb in the Passive voice (‘book’ becomes the subject in place of ‘I’).
2. Add the appropriate form of the verb 'be' to the sentence and use the past participle of the verb (‘find’ is converted to 'found').
3. Add a 'by' followed by the doer of the action.
Thus, the same sentence in the Passive voice is ‘The book could not be found by me’.

Question:
Read the passage carefully and select the best answer to each question out of the given four alternatives.
What is Gandhian philosophy? It is the religious and social ideas adopted and developed by Gandhi, first during his period in South Africa from 1893 to 1914, and later of course in India. These ideas have been further developed by later "Gandhians", most notably, in India by, Vinoba Bhave and Jayaprakash Narayan. Outside of India some of the work of, for example, Martin Luther King Jr. can also be viewed in this light. Understanding the universe to be an organic whole, the philosophy exists on several planes - the spiritual or religious, moral, political, economic, social, individual and collective. The spiritual or religious element and God are at its core. Human nature is regarded as fundamentally virtuous. All individuals are believed to be capable of high moral development and of reform. The twin cardinal principles of Gandhi's thought are truth and nonviolence. It should be remembered that the English word "truth" is an imperfect translation of the Sanskrit, "satya", and "non-violence", an even more imperfect translation of "ahimsa". Derived from "sat" - "that which exists" - "satya" contains a dimension of meaning not usually associated by English speakers with the word "truth". There are other variations, too, which we need not go into here. For Gandhi, truth is the relative truth of truthfulness in word and deed, and the absolute truth - the Ultimate Reality. This ultimate truth is God (as God is also Truth) and morality - the moral laws and code- its basis. Ahimsa, far from meaning mere peacefulness or the absence of overt violence, is understood by Gandhi to denote active love - the polar opposite of violence, or "Himsa", in every sense. The ultimate station Gandhi assigns non-violence stems from two main points. First, if according to the Divine Reality all life is one, then all violence committed towards another is violence towards oneself, towards the collective, whole self, and thus "self"-destructive and counter to the universal law of life, which is love. Second, Gandhi believed that ahimsa is the most powerful force in existence. Had himsa been superior to ahimsa, humankind would long ago have succeeded in destroying itself. The human race certainly could not have progressed as far as it has, even if universal justice remains far off the horizon. From both viewpoints, non-violence or love is regarded as the highest law of humankind.

Question:
What are the twin cardinal principles of Gandhi’s thought?
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2 i.e. truth and non-violence.
It is directly stated in the passage in the following line: ‘The twin cardinal principles of Gandhi's thought are truth and nonviolence’.

Question:

P: The English developed transport and communication on modern lines.
Q: They established the first printing press and newspaper in India.

S: The Press further developed later to inform and educate the masses about the British exploitation of India.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4 i.e. RPQS.
R is the first sentence of the passage as it introduces the theme of the paragraph i.e. modernization of India.
P should follow R as it describes what English did for modernization of India.

Question:
In the following question, a sentence has been given in Direct/Indirect speech. Out of the four alternatives suggested, select the one which best expresses the same sentence in Indirect/Direct speech.
"We were living in Dehradun," they told me.
OP1: They told me that they had been living in Dehradun.
OP2: They told me that they lived in Dehradun.
OP3: They told me this that they had been living in Dehradun.
OP4: They told me this that they were living in Dehradun.
Solution:
The given sentence is in Direct Speech.
The given sentence is in Direct Speech because it quotes actual words. Therefore, it must be changed into Indirect Speech.
We notice that the reporting verb is in the Past tense (‘said’). Hence, a change will be made in the tense of the reported speech.
Also, the first person of the reported speech is changed according to the subject of reporting speech.
In the given question, ‘we’ is changed to ‘they’ and ‘were living’ is changed to ‘had been living’.
Therefore, the sentence in Indirect Speech will be option 1 i.e. They told me that they had been living in Dehradun.

Question:
Rearrange the parts of the sentence in correct order.
P: Freedom of speech is essential for the all-round growth and development of a person as well as a nation as a whole.
Q: A nation filled with people full of discontent can never grow in the right direction.
R: It can even create discomfort and dissatisfaction that leads to stress.
S: Imposing restriction on what one speaks or hears can hamper the development of a person.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 1 i.e. PSRQ.
The first line of the passage must be the one which introduces the theme of the paragraph. Out of all the sentences, sentence Q is the starting line as it introduces the subject of the passage i.e. ‘freedom of speech’.
S should follow Q as it describes what imposing restriction can do if someone is not given the freedom of speech.
R further elaborates the problem which can occur if freedom of speech is not given to individuals. Hence, it is the third sentence in the passage.
Q is the last sentence of the passage. It explains that it eventually affects the nation as the nation cannot grow in the right direction if its people are filled with discontent.

The correct answer is option 2 i.e. PQRS

Since only option 2 contains P as the starting sentence, it is the answer.

The given sentence is in Direct Speech because it quotes actual words. Therefore, it must be changed into Indirect Speech.
We notice that the reporting verb is in the Past tense (‘said’). Hence, a change will be made in the tense of the reported speech.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select 'No Error'.
A focused programme to universalize education and (1)/ skill training would potentially keep (2)/ juveniles from coming into conflict within the law. (3)/ No error.(4)
Solution:
The error is in the third part of the sentence.
The word ‘within’ must be replaced with ‘with’ to make the sentence correct.
The preposition 'within' means 'inside' in spatial, temporal and figurative senses. However, the preposition 'with' means 'accompanying, alongside, by means of, etc.'
Hence, the correct sentence will be: A focused programme to universalize education and skills training would potentially keep juveniles from coming into conflict with the law.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select 'No Error'.
Policymakers will think hard about creating (1)/ an appropriate legal framework to (2)/ prevent the capture of regulatories by special interests. (3)/ No error. (4)
Solution:
The error is in the third part of the sentence.
The word ‘regulatories’ must be replaced with ‘regulation’ to make the sentence correct.
The word 'regulatory' is an adjective, which means 'serving or intended to regulate something.'
The word 'regulation' is a noun, which means 'the action or process of regulating or being regulated.'
Hence, the correct sentence will be: Policymakers will think hard about creating an appropriate legal framework to prevent the capture of regulation by special interests.

Question:

The state has (declined negotiate) any more trade-offs on this proposal or accept calls for stringent transparency requirements.
Solution:

The sentence begins with 'The state has' which indicates Present Perfect tense. Also, the '-ing' form of the verb cannot be used with 'to'.
The sentence will be: The state has declined to negotiate any more trade-offs on this proposal or accept calls for stringent transparency requirements.

Question:

Solution:
The error is in the third part of the sentence.

  • Instead, 'custom' is a more appropriate word. It means 'a traditional and widely accepted way of behaving or doing something that is specific to a particular society, place, or time.'

Correct sentence: Sometimes it appears as if they were deliberately (1)/ limiting their chances of survival in order (2)/ to observe some custom or taboo. (3)/ No error (4)

Question:

I said to my friend, "Be careful, my dog may bite you."
